com.codepotato.model.effects

Class TimeBasedEffect

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.codepotato.model.effects.Effect
      • com.codepotato.model.effects.TimeBasedEffect
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ChorusEffect, EchoEffect, FlangerEffect

    public abstract class TimeBasedEffect
extends Effect
    TimeBasedEffect is an abstract base class for any effect that can be considered "time based". Time based effects all require a delay as an elementary component.
    Author:
    Michael Santer
    See Also:
    EchoEffect, ChorusEffect, and FlangerEffect

        public TimeBasedEffect()

    • Method Detail

      • getDelayTime

        public int getDelayTime()
        Delay time is the amount of time between echos. The Max Delay Time is 1000ms.
        Returns:
        Delay time as a percent of the MAX_DELAY_TIME from 0 - 100.

      • setDelayTime

        public void setDelayTime(int percent)
        Delay time is the amount of time between echos. The Max Delay Time is 1000ms. Given a percent from 0-100, sets the delay time.
        Parameters:
        percent -

      • getWetGain

        public int getWetGain()
        Wet Gain is the volume of the affected sound.
        Returns:
        as a percent from 0-100 of the MaxGain

      • setWetGain

        public void setWetGain(int percent)
        Wet Gain is the volume of the affected sound. Set wetGain given a percent from 0-100
        Parameters:
        percent -

      • getDryGain

        public int getDryGain()
        Dry gain is the volume of the un-affected (original) sound.
        Returns:
        dry gain as a percent from 0-100 of the MaxGain

      • setDryGain

        public void setDryGain(int percent)
        Dry gain is the volume of the un-affected (original) sound. Set dryGain given a percent from 0-100
        Parameters:
        percent -

      • getFeedbackGain

        public int getFeedbackGain()
        Feedback gain is the amount in which the affected sound gets quieter and disappears. With a feedback gain of 0, there will be no repeats of the effected sound. With a feedback gain of 100, the effected sound will repeat forever.
        Returns:
        feedbackGain as a percent of the MaxGain

      • setFeedbackGain

        public void setFeedbackGain(int percent)
        Feedback gain is the amount in which the affected sound gets quieter and disappears. With a feedback gain of 0, there will be no repeats of the effected sound. With a feedback gain of 100, the effected sound will repeat forever. Set feedback given a percent from 0-100 of the MaxGain
        Parameters:
        percent -
